000.name: Stay At Mister Ping's Lost Evocation
000.description: All alone in the deep recesses of the brain, lies the anima of the past... and now he's here, he's near, and he's something to fear... Or, at least, he was, before he was made available on GameJolt. Although SaMPLE was made in Scratch, of all things, I still learned the important concepts of game design, from replayability to how core gameloop systems work in conjunction with each other.

000.name: TRE's Taiko Web Map Editor
000.description: This editor is a .tja file maker for Taiko Web, an online emulator that you can use to play Taiko No Tatsujin inspired maps. As it stands, there is only support for 16 notes per bar, with the notes being either empty, small, or big. You can use the editor here. I learned a lot about HTML Canvas during the development of this project, as well as how one can handle on-screen button inputs, file creation, manipulation, and exporting of said file. In addition to all of that, nearly every graphic was made in MS Paint, as I was working on this from a very limited school computer that only allowed whitelisted programs.

000.name: InfiniRun
000.description: My first "serious" Roblox game that I publicly released. I did not have a lot of Lua experience at the time, so I was quite elated at the fact that I could release something. InfiniRun boasts random tiles, across which you have to run, with different obstacles in a top down view while you run from a wall that's chasing you. There are multiple times of day: Day, Night, and Blood Moon, which change the difficulty of the game. The game has four original sountracks, as well, and you can find InfiniRun on Roblox.

001.name: The Ruby E-Institute of Dreams (The R.E.D.)
001.description: The R.E.D. is an online platform where those with an account can upload and view articles and videos made by other people, thanks to Google Firebase. This mildly humorous website boasts OAuth authentication, Markdown uploads, a live chatting feature where you can talk to fellow students, and a page where you can explore articles made by others. As this was a school project, a lot of things are left to be desired, but given the scope and time that we had, this website, available here, satisfies expectations.

002.name: Zen-Matchers
002.description: "With its quiet colors and simplistic interface, Zen Matchers offers the most relaxing card-matching experience that any player could ask for," says the description of the game, which proves to be quite true from players who've played the game, telling me that they could 'play the game all day' if they were able to. It's a simple UI-based card matching game on Roblox, complete with calm sounds and an aesthetic that's not aggressive to the eyes, and in the making of this project, I learned all about how the different UI systems and containers of Roblox worked, and how they can interact with scripting in Lua. You can play the game for yourself here.
